about.help: Parts was retrieved from Youtube from the channel J. Christopher Anderson, and was created on 3/6/2014.

contents.params: Parts are DNA sequence that encode a functional element of genetic composition.  These elements can exert their effect in the cell as a DNA, or as an RNA or protein encoded by the DNA.

A founding idea of synthetic biology is the objectification of specific DNA sequences as functional primitives that are useful in design. We call these Parts, and there are different kinds of parts such as coding sequences, promoters, RNAs, and the like. In some cases, parts correspond to specific molecules that are encoded by the sequence, such as protein coding sequences and RNAs. In other cases, they correspond to regions of a DNA that proteins act upon with consistent affect, such as promoters and origins of replication.

Though many parts are DNA or RNA elements, most parts encode proteins.  At the DNA level, the region of the sequence that is directly translated 3-bases at a time into protein is called the CDS, or 'CoDing Sequence'.  The proteins that get made into parts are useful by virtue of their molecular function. If you were to write out some arbitrary protein sequence, there is little chance that this protein would fold into a structure and have a function.  However, rare sequences participate in highly-specific and complicated interactions with other molecules.
RNA-Based Parts encode functional RNA molecules, or useful regions of a larger mRNA molecule that encodes a protein.

Parts can also exert their function on the cell at the DNA level.  By this, I mean that the molecule that performs specific interactions with other molecules in the cell is the DNA itself, not an RNA or protein that it encodes.

Origins of Replication: http://openwetware.org/wiki/Arking:JCAOligoTutorial8

An important concept in synthetic biology today is combinatorial design.  Here, sets of related parts are explored in combination with other sets of parts to generate a new device. For this, we must first define families of parts.
